Student Activities Offer Good
Practical Experience

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 21, 1927

A. A. BOARD TO HOLD
DANCE TOMORROW
Immediately after the Loyola-Hopkins game, which will
take place tomorrow, a tea
dance will be held under the
auspices of the A. A. Board.
Price for admission will be
fifty cents per couple or stag.
The same organization will
also give a dance in the evening at 9.00 P. M. The admission fee will be one dollar
per couple or stag.
Both dances will be held in
the C. E. Hall and the music
will be furnished by the Blue
Jay Orchestra.

HOPKINS MAY HAVE
BASKETBALL TEAM
Committee Chosen to Investigate Possibilities of Securing Gymnasium

PUBLIC LECTURES
BEGIN NEXT WEEK
Sir Renolds Rodd, speaking
on "Diplomacy Old and New,"
will deliver the first public
lecture of the year on October
27 at five P. M., in the C. E.
Building.
Sir Reynolds Rodd is especially fitted to talk on this
subject; for he is a man not
only with theoretical, but with
profound practical knowledge
of diplomacy. A graduate of
Oxford, he has devoted almost
his entire life to the diplomatic service of the British
Empire, and has won high
honor. Among his various important missions were ambassador to Italy, minister. to Sweden and delegate to the League
of Nations.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 21, 1927

The Johns Hopkins News-Letter

YES AND NO

FOUNDED 1897

Who knows what words mean? I don't refer to the dictionary
definition; occasionally a word means no more than Messrs. Funk
and Wagnalls say it means; often, it seems to me, it means far,
far less. Originally, words must have been symbols for concrete
objects; something was needed to represent a lion when the lion
was around the corner; it was logical and advantageous to have a
replica of the beast; the word was needed and the word was made.

In this case, obviously, the actual preceded the figurative. But
in the case of the abstract quality, which came first, the symbol or
the attribute? Before some injured cave-woman snarled, "You
have been unfaithful to me," and thus coined a new word, had
man been either loyal or fickle, or did successive generations of
men try to fit themselves to the symbol?

AMERICAN STUDENTS OFFER NO PANACEA
MT. Bertrand R.ussell, the noted English philosopher who is lecturing..in this country, said recently in an interview reported in
Tlie.New Student that "if you cannot liberalize the student, there
is no hope for America. . . . There is too much, tendency in
this cOnntry for liberals to sit around and talk only. It is not
good for a man of 20 to sit around and think all of the world's
problems are solved."
If Mr. Russell believes that the average undergraduate in the
American college can be liberalized to the point where he is seriously-interested in world problems, he is an optimist indeed. Most
college students would not claim to think that all of the world's
problems are solved, but they do not care whether they are solved
or not. And beyond the issues which strike home to them personally—e. g., the prohibition question—they know little or care
little.abOut even national problems.
The av.erage college undergraduate finds himself in a miniature
world :of his own, the complexities of which differ only in degree
from those of the world into which he suddenly finds himself
precipitated after his education has been "completed." He takes
his four years of college more or less for granted, particularly
if he does not have to, work his way through. His exposure to
the problems that grip the world around him is usually limited to
a cursory scanning of the daily newspaper or an occasional plunge
into the depths of one of the so-called "intellectual" magazines.
Few .of the bugaboos that haunt people all over the world come
within his. orbit, except occasionally as curious bits of the day's
news. It is going to be a difficult task to "liberalize" the American
student:
It would be difficult, because most college students realize how
easy it is.for average fairly intelligent Americans to achieve financial success. Liberals—that is, among people who are not inordinately unselfish—are not made from those who are or can be materially satisfied easily. They may be imbued with certain liberal
ideas, and may even believe in the efficacy of certain liberal doctrines, but belief is the limit.
Mr. Russell also says in the same interview that American liberals are "too unrealistic and unwilling to face the facts." The
trouble is that most Americans are too realistic and cannot see
beyond those facts which present themselves to immediate perception. American students are, after all, pre-eminently Americans,
and consequently are the heirs to all the foibles and weaknesses
that are attributable to Americans as a nation.

For all words are weapons, and silence is a vulnerable shield.
The blunt man lays about him with a mallet, or if he be pacific,
he counters heavily, and sharp, subtle stinging darts are smashed
and shattered by his crude hammer blows. Blunt men have
bruised me most with their words; I am stunned by one solid rap,
and when at last I prepare to draw my sword it is too late; it
squeaks in the scabbard, and silence reigns.
Voltaire—yes, I know it's been said before—used a rapier; the
best people do. An experienced fencer enjoys the thrill of combat,; he sees the blood spurt at the bright point of his best sentence,
he parries and thrusts; if he is skillful, he survives; if he is touched,
the wounds fester and he becomes a cynic. There are many men
who wander through life with slim, glittering foils ever in hand;
they are the men who create through annihilation, who stab the
stolid heart of the bourgeois and are hated and admired for their
diabolical agility.
A subtler and usually a less effective weapon is the poets. Slow
poisoning is usually the method of these monsters, who slyly pour
their deadly drops into the warm and tantalizing wines they brew,
so that the crime is done artistically. Death, madness, stupor
or absurdity often result; there are those, however, who are said
to be impervious to this weapon, and who scorn the methods and
their employers.
Our Cal is unique in a preference for pins; their cheapness,
their quantity, or the fact that they help to conceal nakedness even
while they irritate, may explain this.
The Y. M. C. A. will challenge you to creampuffs at ten paces;
a child will sometimes pierce your hide uncomfortably with an
arrow shot from a bow of naiveté; the adolescent hurls mud—
often you may see splashes of it on walls and school yard fences.
Dr. Uhler, if he can remember where he put it, will slap you in the
face with a wooden paddle, and your best friend will stab you
with a stiletto.
But the girl you love . . . I don't know, unless she uses
the old theory that interminable drops of rain-water will crumble
any substance.

HOPKINS GEOLOGISTS SEE MUCH OF
THE WORLD DURING SUMMER MONTHS
Geologists, like the United States
Navy, seem to see the world, at
least if one is to judge by th,eir
summer vacations. Professor Berry was in Peru last summer, Dr
Reid attended the meeting of the
Intel national geo-Physical Conference at Prague, and Dr. Singewald
visited the ore deposits and iron
mines of the Mississippi Valley and
Lake Superior regions.
Dr. Singewald, accompanied by
two graduate students, John C.
Douglas and E. Lee Collins, visited
eighteen States in a two months'
automobile trip. The party spent
the fifth of July at the big round-up
at Bellefourche, S. D., in which
President Coolidge took such a
prominent part. In Missouri they
drove through the still flooded regions where only lines of stakes
protruding above the water marked
off the road. At Kent, Ill., they
visited the fluorspar region, which
comprises the largest producing district of its kind in the world. Fluorspar, Dr. Singewald explained,
is a flux used in the steel industry
and the making of aluminum.

DORM DOINGS

CANE CLUB WILL
MEET TOMORROW

It has been discovered by the residents that the megaphones, which
are forced upon unsuspecting
freshmen, are excellent devices for
making inter-entry calls. Before
this discovery many of the megaphones were plugged at one end and
employed as ash trays and debris
receptors. True, it seems a deed
Which is a bit out of harmony with
those things which are supposed to
foster school spirit, but it is in
full accordance with the dormitory
Spirit.

The first of a series of,meetjugs of the Cane Club will be
held tomorrow at the Phi
Kappa Psi fraternity house
prior to the football game.
The club plans to have short
meetings at the various fraternity houses preceding all
football games played at home
this season.
Fall elections will take place
at this meeting, Ashton Devereux, president of the Cane
Club, announced; and all members are expected to be present. The initiations of new
members, with the customary
horse-and-carriage procession,
is expected to occur in the
early part of November.

The dormitorty is the open house
of every fraternity. There are a
number of freshmen there this year,
SO there should be an interesting
time for the older residents on the
first day of the unrestricted rushing
season.

I. Rosen of the Board of Governors suffered several torn ligaments
in the execution of a difficult dance
step, the "split." Performing his
exhibition on a slippery hardwood
floor, he barely escaped severing
himself into several sections. The
dancing master is one of the eight
surviving members of last year's
board, upon whose action the obtaining of magazines for the Commons Room rests. The residents
regret Rosen's misfortune and will
be glad to see him in action again
charging the Dining Room doors.

• A resident on the north side of
the Dormitory took advantage of
his location in respect to the cooling
north breezes and constructed an
air-cooled refrigerator on his window sill. However,coupled with the
complaints of the management was
the fact that his box attracted a
number of birds from the neighboring wood, so he was forced to keep
his provisions in another
place.

Commons Room was the
center of a
hymn revival meeting.
This is the
first concert staged by the
residents
since the good people of the
,nearby
apartments registered a. complaint.

to purchase towels
this year, as the
canvas curtains in the showers have
been replaced by

No date has as yet been set for
the traditional class rush in which
the two lower classes will participate. Due to the fact that the varsity football season does not come to
a close until December 10, when
Oglethorpe is met, the rush this
year will, in all probability, be un
usually late. In past years the rush
has always taken place on the Saturday after the Thanksgiving holidays, when the football schedule has
been completed. But due to the
post-season game with Oglethorpe,
December 17 appears as the logical
date.
The nature of the rush was also
brought up, but nothing definite was
decided, although several suggestions, some of which 'varied greatly
from last year's mud-and-garbage
battle, were made.

In the report,
of its kind to be left for the especial
purpose of guiding future June
Week Committees,- the 1927 June
Week Committee explains the cause
of the deficit and makes various
recommendations to future June
Week Committees.
Over Calculation

The report which was drawn up
by Thomas McNeal, chairman of
the committee, and J. Albert Abraham, treasurer of the committee,
attributed the deficit to over calculation on the receipts of Alumni Night
and of the Senior Ball. They state,
in the report, that "A conservative
estimate of receipts was balanced
against a liberal estimate of expenditures" in the drawing up of
their budget.
From the experience of other
years a gate receipt of $800 was
considered a conservative figure; the
receipts totaled only about $300,
which, of course,. was enough in
itself to account for more than the
deficit. Added to this was the very
low gate receipt on Alumni Night,
so that the deficit being only $401,
gives proof to the fact that the rest
of the receipt items had been treated
conservatively.
Eight Suggestions

Because of the experience of the
1927 June Week Committee, they
submitted the following recommendations:
1. That June Week be a more
complete Hopkins affair.
2. A reduction in the cost of
the Senior Ball.
3. Reduction in admission price
of Senior Ball.
4. Elimination of lacrosse game.
5. Earlier Alumni campaign.
6. A reduction in the cost of
printing.
7. A reduction in the cost of
booklet programmes.
8. Organized Publicity.
The June Week Committee expressed, in the report, its gratitude
to Mr. John Meyers and Mr. Page
Nelson for their untiring patience
and assistance.

By RALPH KIRKLEY.
Rolling along the steel highway of the Baltimore and Ohio at a
70-mile clip in a train of heavy metal coaches drawn by the newest
and most powerful locomotive in Europe, gives a thrill to the
passenger that is hard to compare with any other sensation of
pleasure.
It was just such a sensation that came to those aboard the "King
George V," the first of the new "king' class of locomotives of the
Great Western Railway of England, when it made successful runs
Monday between Baltimore, Washington and Philadelphia.
For three -weeks immediately preceding, the engine had been
kept at Halethorpe for the Fair of the Iron Horse, throttled down
daily to the pace of the slow-moving transportation pageant. But
Monday the main line of the B. & 0. was cleared for a through
trip and the British locomotive went into action.
Starting its 543-ton train of coaches from Camden Station that
morning without the slightest bit of jerkiness, the King George V
moved smoothly down the tracks, showing no outward sign of the
strain of power in those prettily-painted cylinders. The engine
gradually gathered momentum, and in a few minutes was swinging along toward Washington. Through the "bad lands" on the
outskirts of the city, past the fair grounds at Halethorpe, over
the Carrollton viaduct near Relay, it rolled on toward Washington,
increasing its speed as the British engineer opened the throttle.
In the dynamometer car, directly behind the tender, sat a number
of ralroad men intently watching various scientific instruments
recording the number of feet traveled per second, the draw-bar
pull, the boiler - pressure, and other power and distance measurements.
Then came the thrill. The dial indicator registered 70 miles
per hour. A spirit of tenseness showed itself in the faces of the
men in the car. After all, this was a brand new engine, not yet
tuned in service, running on strange rails. Anything might
happen.
The hand of the dial moved again and electric pens, magnetically
controlled and writing on a chart, clicked off more than 100 feet
a second—seventy-six miles an hour! The rhythmic rattle of the
coaches merged into a steady hu.m. Booming on the up-grade,
the Capitol Limited shot past in one dark streak. Telephone poles
came and went with a swift, rigid motion. On the other side, a
blurred freight train roared by, its cars a rapid succession of
flashes. The throttle was seventy-five per cent open, sending

these 650 tons of steel on a rampage.
But this couldn't keep up. There were questionable curves
ahead. One of the tense faces in the dynamometer car suddenly
opened its mouth in terse comment: "Too damned fast. Better
cut it down some."
The warning was telephoned to the cab and the train slowed
down to a more moderate pace. That maximum speed was not
reached again, neither on the return to Baltimore nor on the round

pre-war

trip to Philadelphia.
The first thrill was over, but the novelty refused to wear off,
for there was plenty of food for thought to sustain the interest
of the trip. A little over a century ago, a dinky little steam
engine, the "Stourbridge Lion," was sent to these shores from
England—the first locomotive to run on rails in America. And
here now was another British engine, at the other end of the scale,
the last word in modern stearn power in Europe, again hauling
an American train. A pleasant occupation to glance back over
the perspective of a hundred years and picture in the mind's eye
the successive stages bridging the vast gap between these two
iron horses.
Other associated ideas kept drawing up for review—the striking differences, for instance, between the English engine and the
typical American locomotive. The latter is usually described in
appearance as monster-like, massive, overwhelming, formidable;
while the "King George V" reminds one more of the greyhound,
sleek, trim, slender, its potential resources hidden beneath the
surface. The English locomotive has no bell, no headlight and
none of the other complicated safety devices required in this
country, which gives the locomotive here its formidable aspect.
The "King George V," painted bright green and gold, with
simple lines and rounded edges, looks like some great toy when
placed beside a President engine of the Capitol Limited, which
has a more rugged symmetry. In point of performance, there is
not much basis for comparison between the two engines, for the
railroad problems of England and the United States are widely
divergent because of geographical differences. England has none
of the steep mountain grades and curves of this country.
In addition to the dynamometer car, the "King George V"
pulled three individual seat coaches, two Pullman cars and an
official observation car—a train heavier by 50 tons than the
average large passenger train run in England.
Altogether, it was an unusual and entertaining trip—a novel
variation, in a new key, of the song of the twin-track trail.

The Johns Hopkins News-Letter

YES AND NO

FOUNDED 1897

Who knows what words mean? I don't refer to the dictionary
definition; occasionally a word means no more than Messrs. Funk
and Wagnalls say it means; often, it seems to me, it means far,
far less. Originally, words must have been symbols for concrete
objects; something was needed to represent a lion when the lion
was around the corner; it was logical and advantageous to have a
replica of the beast; the word was needed and the word was made.

AMERICAN STUDENTS OFFER NO PANACEA
MT. Bertrand R.ussell, the noted English philosopher who is lecturing..in this country, said recently in an interview reported in
Tlie.New Student that "if you cannot liberalize the student, there
is no hope for America. . . . There is too much, tendency in
this cOnntry for liberals to sit around and talk only. It is not
good for a man of 20 to sit around and think all of the world's
problems are solved."
If Mr. Russell believes that the average undergraduate in the
American college can be liberalized to the point where he is seriously-interested in world problems, he is an optimist indeed. Most
college students would not claim to think that all of the world's
problems are solved, but they do not care whether they are solved
or not. And beyond the issues which strike home to them personally—e. g., the prohibition question—they know little or care
little.abOut even national problems.
The av.erage college undergraduate finds himself in a miniature
world :of his own, the complexities of which differ only in degree
from those of the world into which he suddenly finds himself
precipitated after his education has been "completed." He takes
his four years of college more or less for granted, particularly
if he does not have to, work his way through. His exposure to
the problems that grip the world around him is usually limited to
a cursory scanning of the daily newspaper or an occasional plunge
into the depths of one of the so-called "intellectual" magazines.
Few .of the bugaboos that haunt people all over the world come
within his. orbit, except occasionally as curious bits of the day's
news. It is going to be a difficult task to "liberalize" the American
student:
It would be difficult, because most college students realize how
easy it is.for average fairly intelligent Americans to achieve financial success. Liberals—that is, among people who are not inordinately unselfish—are not made from those who are or can be materially satisfied easily. They may be imbued with certain liberal
ideas, and may even believe in the efficacy of certain liberal doctrines, but belief is the limit.
Mr. Russell also says in the same interview that American liberals are "too unrealistic and unwilling to face the facts." The
trouble is that most Americans are too realistic and cannot see
beyond those facts which present themselves to immediate perception. American students are, after all, pre-eminently Americans,
and consequently are the heirs to all the foibles and weaknesses
that are attributable to Americans as a nation.

For all words are weapons, and silence is a vulnerable shield.
The blunt man lays about him with a mallet, or if he be pacific,
he counters heavily, and sharp, subtle stinging darts are smashed
and shattered by his crude hammer blows. Blunt men have
bruised me most with their words; I am stunned by one solid rap,
and when at last I prepare to draw my sword it is too late; it
squeaks in the scabbard, and silence reigns.
Voltaire—yes, I know it's been said before—used a rapier; the
best people do. An experienced fencer enjoys the thrill of combat,; he sees the blood spurt at the bright point of his best sentence,
he parries and thrusts; if he is skillful, he survives; if he is touched,
the wounds fester and he becomes a cynic. There are many men
who wander through life with slim, glittering foils ever in hand;
they are the men who create through annihilation, who stab the
stolid heart of the bourgeois and are hated and admired for their
diabolical agility.
A subtler and usually a less effective weapon is the poets. Slow
poisoning is usually the method of these monsters, who slyly pour
their deadly drops into the warm and tantalizing wines they brew,
so that the crime is done artistically. Death, madness, stupor
or absurdity often result; there are those, however, who are said
to be impervious to this weapon, and who scorn the methods and
their employers.
Our Cal is unique in a preference for pins; their cheapness,
their quantity, or the fact that they help to conceal nakedness even
while they irritate, may explain this.
The Y. M. C. A. will challenge you to creampuffs at ten paces;
a child will sometimes pierce your hide uncomfortably with an
arrow shot from a bow of naiveté; the adolescent hurls mud—
often you may see splashes of it on walls and school yard fences.
Dr. Uhler, if he can remember where he put it, will slap you in the
face with a wooden paddle, and your best friend will stab you
with a stiletto.
But the girl you love . . . I don't know, unless she uses
the old theory that interminable drops of rain-water will crumble
any substance.

HOPKINS GEOLOGISTS SEE MUCH OF
THE WORLD DURING SUMMER MONTHS
Geologists, like the United States
Navy, seem to see the world, at
least if one is to judge by th,eir
summer vacations. Professor Berry was in Peru last summer, Dr
Reid attended the meeting of the
Intel national geo-Physical Conference at Prague, and Dr. Singewald
visited the ore deposits and iron
mines of the Mississippi Valley and
Lake Superior regions.
Dr. Singewald, accompanied by
two graduate students, John C.
Douglas and E. Lee Collins, visited
eighteen States in a two months'
automobile trip. The party spent
the fifth of July at the big round-up
at Bellefourche, S. D., in which
President Coolidge took such a
prominent part. In Missouri they
drove through the still flooded regions where only lines of stakes
protruding above the water marked
off the road. At Kent, Ill., they
visited the fluorspar region, which
comprises the largest producing district of its kind in the world. Fluorspar, Dr. Singewald explained,
is a flux used in the steel industry
and the making of aluminum.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 21, 1927

VELI

DORM DOINGS

CANE CLUB WILL
MEET TOMORROW

It has been discovered by the residents that the megaphones, which
are forced upon unsuspecting
freshmen, are excellent devices for
making inter-entry calls. Before
this discovery many of the megaphones were plugged at one end and
employed as ash trays and debris
receptors. True, it seems a deed
Which is a bit out of harmony with
those things which are supposed to
foster school spirit, but it is in
full accordance with the dormitory
Spirit.

The first of a series of,meetjugs of the Cane Club will be
held tomorrow at the Phi
Kappa Psi fraternity house
prior to the football game.
The club plans to have short
meetings at the various fraternity houses preceding all
football games played at home
this season.
Fall elections will take place
at this meeting, Ashton Devereux, president of the Cane
Club, announced; and all members are expected to be present. The initiations of new
members, with the customary
horse-and-carriage procession,
is expected to occur in the
early part of November.

NITY

it

*

*

*

The dormitorty is the open house
of every fraternity. There are a
number of freshmen there this year,
SO there should be an interesting
time for the older residents on the
first day of the unrestricted rushing
season.

I. Rosen of the Board of Governors suffered several torn ligaments
in the execution of a difficult dance
step, the "split." Performing his
exhibition on a slippery hardwood
floor, he barely escaped severing
himself into several sections. The
dancing master is one of the eight
surviving members of last year's
board, upon whose action the obtaining of magazines for the Commons Room rests. The residents
regret Rosen's misfortune and will
be glad to see him in action again
charging the Dining Room doors.
*

*

*

• A resident on the north side of
the Dormitory took advantage of
his location in respect to the cooling
north breezes and constructed an
air-cooled refrigerator on his window sill. However,coupled with the
complaints of the management was
the fact that his box attracted a
number of birds from the neighboring wood, so he was forced to keep
his provisions in another
place.
*

*

Last Sunday evening the
Commons Room was the
center of a
hymn revival meeting.
This is the
first concert staged by the
residents
since the good people of the
,nearby
apartments registered a. complaint.

Many residents have been forced
to purchase towels
this year, as the
canvas curtains in the showers have
been replaced by
rubber ones.

No date has as yet been set for
the traditional class rush in which
the two lower classes will participate. Due to the fact that the varsity football season does not come to
a close until December 10, when
Oglethorpe is met, the rush this
year will, in all probability, be un
usually late. In past years the rush
has always taken place on the Saturday after the Thanksgiving holidays, when the football schedule has
been completed. But due to the
post-season game with Oglethorpe,
December 17 appears as the logical
date.
The nature of the rush was also
brought up, but nothing definite was
decided, although several suggestions, some of which 'varied greatly
from last year's mud-and-garbage
battle, were made.

In the report,
of its kind to be left for the especial
purpose of guiding future June
Week Committees,- the 1927 June
Week Committee explains the cause
of the deficit and makes various
recommendations to future June
Week Committees.
Over Calculation

The report which was drawn up
by Thomas McNeal, chairman of
the committee, and J. Albert Abraham, treasurer of the committee,
attributed the deficit to over calculation on the receipts of Alumni Night
and of the Senior Ball. They state,
in the report, that "A conservative
estimate of receipts was balanced
against a liberal estimate of expenditures" in the drawing up of
their budget.
From the experience of other
years a gate receipt of $800 was
considered a conservative figure; the
receipts totaled only about $300,
which, of course,. was enough in
itself to account for more than the
deficit. Added to this was the very
low gate receipt on Alumni Night,
so that the deficit being only $401,
gives proof to the fact that the rest
of the receipt items had been treated
conservatively.
Eight Suggestions

Because of the experience of the
1927 June Week Committee, they
submitted the following recommendations:
1. That June Week be a more
complete Hopkins affair.
2. A reduction in the cost of
the Senior Ball.
3. Reduction in admission price
of Senior Ball.
4. Elimination of lacrosse game.
5. Earlier Alumni campaign.
6. A reduction in the cost of
printing.
7. A reduction in the cost of
booklet programmes.
8. Organized Publicity.
The June Week Committee expressed, in the report, its gratitude
to Mr. John Meyers and Mr. Page
Nelson for their untiring patience
and assistance.

By RALPH KIRKLEY.
Rolling along the steel highway of the Baltimore and Ohio at a
70-mile clip in a train of heavy metal coaches drawn by the newest
and most powerful locomotive in Europe, gives a thrill to the
passenger that is hard to compare with any other sensation of
pleasure.
It was just such a sensation that came to those aboard the "King
George V," the first of the new "king' class of locomotives of the
Great Western Railway of England, when it made successful runs
Monday between Baltimore, Washington and Philadelphia.
For three -weeks immediately preceding, the engine had been
kept at Halethorpe for the Fair of the Iron Horse, throttled down
daily to the pace of the slow-moving transportation pageant. But
Monday the main line of the B. & 0. was cleared for a through
trip and the British locomotive went into action.
Starting its 543-ton train of coaches from Camden Station that
morning without the slightest bit of jerkiness, the King George V
moved smoothly down the tracks, showing no outward sign of the
strain of power in those prettily-painted cylinders. The engine
gradually gathered momentum, and in a few minutes was swinging along toward Washington. Through the "bad lands" on the
outskirts of the city, past the fair grounds at Halethorpe, over
the Carrollton viaduct near Relay, it rolled on toward Washington,
increasing its speed as the British engineer opened the throttle.
In the dynamometer car, directly behind the tender, sat a number
of ralroad men intently watching various scientific instruments
recording the number of feet traveled per second, the draw-bar
pull, the boiler - pressure, and other power and distance measurements.
Then came the thrill. The dial indicator registered 70 miles
per hour. A spirit of tenseness showed itself in the faces of the
men in the car. After all, this was a brand new engine, not yet
tuned in service, running on strange rails. Anything might
happen.
The hand of the dial moved again and electric pens, magnetically
controlled and writing on a chart, clicked off more than 100 feet
a second—seventy-six miles an hour! The rhythmic rattle of the
coaches merged into a steady hu.m. Booming on the up-grade,
the Capitol Limited shot past in one dark streak. Telephone poles
came and went with a swift, rigid motion. On the other side, a
blurred freight train roared by, its cars a rapid succession of
flashes. The throttle was seventy-five per cent open, sending

these 650 tons of steel on a rampage.
But this couldn't keep up. There were questionable curves
ahead. One of the tense faces in the dynamometer car suddenly
opened its mouth in terse comment: "Too damned fast. Better
cut it down some."
The warning was telephoned to the cab and the train slowed
down to a more moderate pace. That maximum speed was not
reached again, neither on the return to Baltimore nor on the round

pre-war

trip to Philadelphia.
The first thrill was over, but the novelty refused to wear off,
for there was plenty of food for thought to sustain the interest
of the trip. A little over a century ago, a dinky little steam
engine, the "Stourbridge Lion," was sent to these shores from
England—the first locomotive to run on rails in America. And
here now was another British engine, at the other end of the scale,
the last word in modern stearn power in Europe, again hauling
an American train. A pleasant occupation to glance back over
the perspective of a hundred years and picture in the mind's eye
the successive stages bridging the vast gap between these two
iron horses.
Other associated ideas kept drawing up for review—the striking differences, for instance, between the English engine and the
typical American locomotive. The latter is usually described in
appearance as monster-like, massive, overwhelming, formidable;
while the "King George V" reminds one more of the greyhound,
sleek, trim, slender, its potential resources hidden beneath the
surface. The English locomotive has no bell, no headlight and
none of the other complicated safety devices required in this
country, which gives the locomotive here its formidable aspect.
The "King George V," painted bright green and gold, with
simple lines and rounded edges, looks like some great toy when
placed beside a President engine of the Capitol Limited, which
has a more rugged symmetry. In point of performance, there is
not much basis for comparison between the two engines, for the
railroad problems of England and the United States are widely
divergent because of geographical differences. England has none
of the steep mountain grades and curves of this country.
In addition to the dynamometer car, the "King George V"
pulled three individual seat coaches, two Pullman cars and an
official observation car—a train heavier by 50 tons than the
average large passenger train run in England.
Altogether, it was an unusual and entertaining trip—a novel
variation, in a new key, of the song of the twin-track trail.
